{{refimprove|date=May 2009}}
'''Da Lata''' (meaning "from the tin" in Portuguese) are a British group formed in 1994 by [[Chris Franck]] and [[Patrick Forge]]. They combine [[Afro-Brazilian]] influences with other strands from the melting pot of their native London. Franck and Forge previously worked together with the Brighton-based group [[Batu (group)|Batu]] before setting up Da Lata as a more studio based project. Franck is the main creative force as songwriter, producer and multi-instrumentalist, whereas Forge, better known as a [[DJ]] and broadcaster, is credited as co-producer. They made three albums for [[Palm Pictures]]: ''Songs from the Tin''(2000) and ''Serious'' (2003) and a collection of their remix work for other artists, ''Remixes'' which featured their interpretations of songs by [[Femi Kuti]], [[Luciano]], [[Bebel Gilberto]] and [[Sly and Robbie]], among others. After a hiatus of several years, the pair started work on a new album in 2011. It was scheduled for release in early 2013.<ref name="GU">{{cite web|url=http://dalata.bandcamp.com/album/going-underground-2-tracks|title=Going Underground (2 tracks)|work=[[Bandcamp]]|publisher=Da Lata|accessdate=8 November 2012}}</ref>
==Early work==
Da Lata's first release was as '''Trio Da Lata''' for Brownswood Records in Japan. The song "Deep Water" featured former [[Batu (group)|Batu]] vocalist Sharon Scott. However, it was their next release, a version of [[Edu Lobo]]'s classic "Ponteio" that garnered attention, crossing over between [[House music|house]] and jazz-dance audiences. "Ponteio" was supported particularly strongly in Japan and in New York by the Body&Soul DJs. Despite the success of this single, Da Lata was put on hold for a few years whilst Chris Franck wrote, produced and toured with [[Smoke City]]. In 1998, they recorded a song that had been initially demoed four years earlier; it was on the strength of the song "Pra Manha" that they were signed to [[Chris Blackwell]]'s Palm Pictures.
==Albums== ===''Songs from the Tin''===
Released in 2000, Da Lata's first album enlisted help from London-based Brazilian vocalist Liliana Chachian, who previously featured on "Ponteio", and percussionist Oli Savill. Strongly influenced by classic [[Música popular brasileira|MPB]] from the late sixties and seventies, ''Songs from the Tin'' also bears the influence of dance music, comparing Da Lata with [[Masters at Work|Nuyorican Soul]]. [[Barnes & Noble]]'s online guide said:
{{quote|"Impeccably produced, weighty tracks that unroll like an evening at a great dance club, where the segue is just as important as the track itself, and the transportive aspects of the music -- swelling strings, whistling synths, cool solos, and incessant percussion". -- ''Aim for Ecstasy''}}
===''Serious''===
Parting company from Liliana Chachian and Oli Savill, Da Lata's second album took on other [[world music]] influences, particularly [[Afrobeat]], to present a more diverse sound, though the Brazilian influence remained strong. Featuring guest performances from [[Baaba Maal]], Jhelisa, Bembé Segué, and Brazilian accordionist Marcelo Jeneci, ''Serious'' "proves that Da Lata are one of the few capable of an intriguing, along-lasting dance/world fusion".<ref name="Bush">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/serious-mw0000326505|title=Serious|last=Bush|first=John|work=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=8 November 2012}}</ref>
===''Fabiola''===
After leaving Palm Pictures, Da Lata released tracks in Japan ("Ronco Da Cuica") and in the UK ("This Is Not Your Job"), both of which were updated for release on their follow-up album ''Fabiola''. A [[cover version]] of [[The Jam]]'s "[[Going Underground]]", with vocals by Floetic Lara, was released as a single in December 2012.<ref name="GU" /> The album ''Fabiola'' was released in October 2013 on Agogo Records.

[https://www.horizon.tv/en_ie/live-channels/live-channel.html/28863015393/Disc-Channel-%2B1.html Watch live] (+1, Ireland only) }} '''Discovery''' (formerly '''Discovery Channel''') is an English speaking channel which targets the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Ireland]], operated by [[Discovery Networks Western Europe]]. The channel's programming is based on programming produced by Discovery Networks Europe, [[Discovery Channel (Canada)|Discovery Channel Canada]] and [[Discovery Channel]] from the United States. ==History== It first became available in the UK on 1 April 1989 when Discovery Channel Europe launched. It was the first extension of the Discovery Channel outside the United States.{{cite web |url=http://corporate.discovery.com/pdf/timeline/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090101231547/http://corporate.discovery.com/pdf/timeline/ |archivedate=1 January 2009 |df=dmy }} Prior to 1993, UK viewers could receive the channel from [[Intelsat]] satellites at 27.5° West. In July 1993, the Discovery Channel launched on the [[Astra 1C]] analogue satellite on the popular 19.2° East position where it used to broadcast only in the evening, starting at 4{{nbsp}}pm. On Astra, the daytime space was filled by [[CMT Europe]] until 1994, when [[Discovery Real Time|TLC]] (later on [[Discovery Real Time|Discovery Home & Leisure]]) moved there. Eventually, Discovery Home & Leisure would broadcast from the morning to 4{{nbsp}}pm when Discovery Channel took over and would broadcast for ten hours until 2{{nbsp}}am. With the launch of [[Sky (United Kingdom)|Sky Digital]] in October 1998, Discovery Channel moved its start time to 8{{nbsp}}am, broadcasting for 18 hours per day. The time-shift channel, Discovery Channel +1, launched at the same time, as did several sister channels.{{cite news|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/services/motion-pictures/4797847-1.html |title=Discovery Maps Out Its Digital Bskyb Services |date=19 August 1998 |publisher=The Hollywood Reporter }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Analogue broadcasts were terminated in 2001. On 22 May 2006, [[Discovery HD]] was made available on Sky as part of the [[Sky+ HD]] launch line up. It was also made available on [[Virgin Media]]'s cable service on 1 April 2010.{{cite web|url=http://mediacentre.virginmedia.com/Stories/Virgin-Media-customers-to-get-Discovery-HD-channel-and-more-HD-programmes-on-demand-17b.aspx|title=Virgin Media customers to get Discovery HD channel and more HD programmes on demand|publisher=Virgin Media|date=10 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130412034845/http://mediacentre.virginmedia.com/Stories/Virgin-Media-customers-to-get-Discovery-HD-channel-and-more-HD-programmes-on-demand-17b.aspx|archivedate=12 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} From 30 June 2011 Discovery HD began to [[simulcast]] Discovery Channel in [[High-definition television|high-definition]] rather than use a separate schedule. The channel briefly had a 90-minute timeshift, called Discovery Channel +1.5. It launched on 25 June 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.theairwaves.net/index.php/channelnews/2914-discovery-launches-second-timeshirt-service|title=Discovery launches second timeshift service|publisher=The Airwaves|date=25 June 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724095309/http://www.theairwaves.net/index.php/channelnews/2914-discovery-launches-second-timeshirt-service|archivedate=24 July 2011}} It was replaced by [[Discovery Science (European TV channel)|Discovery Science +1]] on 21 April 2008. An Irish advertising feed was launched in 2010. Sky Media Ireland operates the channel's output in terms of advertising, sponsorship and scheduling.{{cite web|last=O'Carroll |first=Tristan |url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/news/971207/Discovery-appoints-Sky-Media-TV-ad-sales-Ireland/ |title=Discovery appoints Sky Media for TV ad sales in Ireland |publisher=Media Week |date=1 December 2009 |accessdate=21 July 2013}} In January 2011, Discovery Channel UK released its new look which places its emphasis on the D-globe logo. The project was created by DixonBaxi and Double G Studios.[http://www.theidentgallery.com/discovery-2011.php Discovery Channel UK – Current Idents (2011)][http://www.theidentgallery.com/discovery-2011-misc-1.php Discovery Channel UK – Current Bumpers (2011)] On 25 January 2017, Discovery UK announced that they were in a dispute over the fees paid by Sky for broadcast rights and for a time it seemed as though the channels could be removed from the platform after the end of that month.{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/discovery-in-extraordinary-row-with-sky-2017-1|title=Discovery UK is threatening to switch off its channels on Sky in an extraordinary disagreement|newspaper=Business Insider|language=en|access-date=2017-01-26}} However, an agreement was reached and programming continued uninterrupted.https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2017/01/31/discovery-sky-reach-eleventh-hour-deal-stop-eurosport-blackout/ On 1 May 2018, Discovery moved from 520 to 125 as [[Sky plc|Sky]] changed their channel list, as well as adding [[Netflix]] and [[Spotify]]. [[TLC (UK and Ireland)|TLC]] moved from 125 to 140. TLC +2 closed on 27 April 2018 to make way for Discovery Turbo +1. ==Programming== *''[[MythBusters]]'' *''[[American Chopper]]'' *''[[Extreme Engineering]]'' *''[[How Do They Do It?]]'' *''[[How It's Made]]'' *''[[Deadliest Catch]]'' *''[[Storm Chasers (TV series)|Storm Chasers]]'' *''[[Man vs. Wild]]'' (known as ''Bear Grylls: Born Survivor'') *''Modern Top Ten'' *''[[Wheeler Dealers]]'' *''[[Coal (TV series)|Coal]]'' *''[[Fifth Gear]]'' *''Bugs, Bites and Parasites'' *''[[X-Ray Mega Airport]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.discoveryuk.com/}} {{Discovery Communications}} {{Media in the United Kingdom|television}} [[Category:Discovery, Inc.]] [[Category:Discovery Channel in the United Kingdom|Discovery Channel in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Television in Iceland]] [[Category:Television stations in Ireland]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1989]] [[Category:Television channel articles with incorrect naming style]]

{{short description|1991 Jazz composition}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2011}} {{Infobox song | Name= Double Helix | Cover = DH portfolio cover.jpg | Alt = | Caption =Cover for score and parts | Type = Composition | Artist = [[Jack Cooper (musician)|Jack Cooper]] | Released = 1995 | Format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | Recorded = 1993 | Studio = [[Omega Recording Studios|Omega Recording]], Rockville, Maryland | Composer = [[Jack Cooper (musician)|Jack Cooper]] | Genre = [[Jazz]], [[blues]] | Misc = }} "'''Double Helix'''" is an original music composition written for 17-piece [[jazz]] orchestra in 1991.{{cite web|url=http://www.reallygoodmusic.com/rgm.jsp?page=itemDetail&iid=123206|title=Really Good Music|website=Reallygoodmusic.com|accessdate=January 24, 2018}} The recording of "Double Helix" also goes by the title "Twice is Nice" (as a sound file){{cite web|url=http://www.firstcom.com/#/en/search-results.aspx?searchtype=quick&predictsearch=true&keyword=twice+is+nice&tracks_title=Track+Title|title=FirstCom Music - Online Production Music Library|website=Firstcom.com|accessdate=January 24, 2018}} when distributed worldwide as production music. The work has been used and heard around the world for music, media, and entertainment broadcasts. ==Background== ''Double Helix'' was first written in 1991 as a commission for the [[Southern California School Band and Orchestra Association|SCSBOA]] Honor Jazz Ensemble and premiered at [[Disneyland]] that year.[http://linahonmusic.com/ James Linahon] called Cooper in 1991 to commission a new work for the [http://www.scsboa.org/ SCSBOA] jazz group, Linahon would conduct them later that year. Late in 1991 Jack Bullock (jazz editor for [[Alfred Music Publishing|Columbia Pictures Publications/Belwin]], (aka [[Alfred Music Publishing|CPP Belwin]] and currently [[Alfred Music Publishing|Belwin Jazz, a Division of Alred Music Publishing]]) hired [[Jack Cooper (musician)|Jack Cooper]] as a staff writer for new jazz ensemble works.{{cite web|url=http://www.alfred.com/|title=Home|website=Alfred.com|accessdate=January 24, 2018}} Jack Bullock heard his writing done for the [[The Jazz Knights|U.S. Army ''Jazz Knights'']].CPP/Belwin composer [[:nl:Carl Strommen|Carl Strommen]] forwarded Cooper's demo tape to [http://www.alfred.com/Company/Authors/JackBullock.aspx Jack Bullock] after hearing the [[The Jazz Knights|U.S.M.A. ''Jazz Knights'']] perform while Cooper was with the group during that time. The first piece Bullock decided to publish (and record) was ''Double Helix''.Review: BD Guide, November/December 1993, Village Press, Inc. J. Richard Dunscomb (reviewer), rated: ''the very best'', page 36 The work was recorded at [[Omega Recording Studios]] in [[Rockville, Maryland]] for the 1993 [[Alfred Music Publishing|CPP/Belwin]] Jazz catalogue of new published works.1993 CPP/Belwin New Music Jazz Ensemble Catalogue, music for credits and opening track for demo, ''Double Helix'' Later In 1994, Canadian beverage giant [[Seagram]] bought a part of [[Time Warner]] and the [[Warner/Chappell Music|Warner Music Publishing division]] of that company acquired [[Alfred Music Publishing|CPP/Belwin]]. ''Double Helix'' was now distributed by [[Warner Brothers Music]] publications and the company made the move to allow [[FirstCom]] and [[Universal Music Publishing Group|Universal Publishing Production Music]] to have access to a limited number of [[Alfred Music Publishing|CPP/Belwin]] sound files. The recordings from [[Omega Recording Studios|Omega Studios]] for [[Alfred Music Publishing|CPP/Belwin]] were of very high quality as well as the music itself that was being written and acquired for the catalogue. While the original [[Alfred Music Publishing|CPP/Belwin]] sound file of ''Double Helix'' continues to be widely used in the media, the rights to the print music were acquired back by the composer in 2006. The print music division of [[Time Warner]] was [[Corporate spin-off|sold]] to [[Alfred Music Publishing]] in June 2005 which made a great deal of the older [[Alfred Music Publishing|CPP/Belwin]] print music catalogue obsolete. At that time it was best to move ''Double Helix'' (the print music) to a company who would keep the work in distribution for a much longer period; the print music is now distributed and sold by Really Good Music Publishing. The music and sound file of ''Double Helix'' has been and is still frequently utilized for media production in [[television]] and [[radio]].''Double Helix'' is in repeated syndicated T.V. broadcasts around the world The [[ASCAP]] distributions have far exceeded the original royalty payments made through sale of the print music by [[Alfred Music Publishing|CPP/Belwin]]. ==Composition== The work itself is 170 measures and based on a [[Blues#Form|Blues form]] in the key of ''f minor''. The smaller 12 measure sub-form repeats numerous times; the overall work mimicks a hybrid [[Sonata form]] with an [[Sonata form#Exposition|exposition/statement]], [[Musical development|development]] (with improvisation section), and [[Recapitulation (music)|recap]] (or [[Repetition (music)|restatement]]). ===The form and layout of ''Double Helix''=== {| class="wikitable" | style="width:300px; text-align:center;"|'''Double Helix''' |- |align=center| {| cellspacing="1" class="wikitable" |- style="text-align:center;" | style="width:50px;"| Measures
1-12 | style="width:50px;"| 13-48 | style="width:50px;"| 49-64 | style="width:50px;"| 77-88 | style="width:50px;"| 89-112 | style="width:50px;"| 113-124 | style="width:50px;"| 125-144 | style="width:50px;"| 145-156 | style="width:50px;"| 157-170 |- style="text-align:center;" | style="width:50px;"| Introduction | style="width:50px;"| statement
melody/song | style="width:50px;"| interlude
''send off'' | style="width:50px;"| open improvisation/
background figures | style="width:50px;"| saxophone section
soli | style="width:50px;"| ''stop time''
[[A cappella|Acappella]]
brass | style="width:50px;"| development | style="width:50px;"| recap of
melody/song | style="width:50px;"| coda/Finé |} |} ==Reviews== {{Album ratings | rev1 = Band Directors Guide
(BD Guide) | rev1Score = (*)The Very BestDunscomb, J. Richard, Review, ''Double Helix'', BD Guide. Nov./Dec. 1993. Vol. 8, No. 2, pp.36 }} {{quote |"Aptly titled, this original work spirals its way into the world of contemporary big band swing music. The voicing selections are superb. It comes off sounding much more difficult than it sctually is...The driving into the head (section) set(s) up the soloist, who emerges with a roar from the full ensemble scoring...The shout chorus is memorable and, like the rest of the chart, it contains terrific dynamic contrasts." |Dick Dunscomb ''BD Guide'' (review, 1993) }} ==Use in media== "Double Helix" has been used as feature, interlude, and background music in the United Kingdom,''Deal or No Deal'' (TV Series), Episode 49067/011 [[United Kingdom|U.K.]], [[PRS for Music|PRS]]/[http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] April–August 2013 distribution the Czech Republic,[[Performance rights organisation|OSA]]. credits as per [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] distribution, Aug. 2011 the Netherlands,[http://www.dr.dk/ DR (broadcaster)|Danish Radio P2, TROS], used often as library music, [http://www.bumastemra.nl/ BUMA] through current [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] distribution, confirmed May 25, 2010 Ireland,[http://www.imro.ie/ IMRO] credits as per [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] distribution, Feb. 2005 Canada,[http://www.socan.ca/ SOCAN] credits as per [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] distribution, Feb. 2001 Romania,[http://www.ucmr-ada.ro/ UCMR-ADA] credits as per [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] distribution, Feb. 2009 France,[http://www.sacem.fr/cms/site/en/home?pop=1 SACEM], credits as per [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] distribution Norway,''50 Hottest Vegas Moments'' (2005), January 17, 2005 (USA) first aired, confirmed through [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] July Distribution, 2006 - episode aired 14 times during that time period[http://www.teosto.fi/teosto/websivut.nsf Teosto] [http://www.tono.no/ TONO] credits as per [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] distribution, May 2007 Finland, Hong Kong,[http://www.cash.org.hk/en/home.do CASH] credits as per [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] distribution and Japan.Under the title ''Twice is Nice'', ''Double Helix'' [http://www.jasrac.or.jp/ejhp/index.htm JASRAC] ''UNCUT (ETV) - Meg Ryan,'' first aired May 7, 1996 Television shows using the work include ''[[The Jenny Jones Show]]'',''[http://www.tv.com/shows/jenny-jones/ The Jenny Jones Show]'' (1995). Episodes ''Double Helix'' is used on include "Celebrity Look-A-Likes" and "Second Annual Jenny Jones Awards", [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] Jan. 1999 distribution ''F.Y.E.'', ''[[E! Entertainment]]'' shows (2),''[http://tv.nytimes.com/show/160981/Vegas-Showgirls-Nearly-Famous/overview ''Vegas Showgirls: Nearly Famous]'' (TV Series 2001-2003), [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] distribution records April and July 2002 ''[[Access Hollywood]]'',''[http://www.tv.com/shows/access-hollywood/ Access Hollywood]'' (TV series) Episode dated May 7, 2001, #0435, confirmed through [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] Jan. distribution 2002 ''[[Johnny Bravo|JBVO: Your All Request Cartoon Show]]'',''Johnny Bravo'' (TV Series), Episodes #14 and #24 from ''JBVO: Your All Request Cartoon Show'', [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] April–September 2001 distribution ''[[American Restoration]]'',''American Restoration'' (TV/Cable series), Episode ''Surfing The Strip'', [http://www.ascap.com/ ASCAP] April–August 2013 distribution ''[[Deal or No Deal (UK game show)|Deal or No Deal (UK)]]'', and ''[[Extra (U.S. TV program)|Extra]]''. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{OCLC|668441746}} * [http://iswcnet.cisac.org/iswcnet/MWI/result/detail.do?workDetails=0 ISWC T-070.045.419-8] * [http://www.reallygoodmusic.com/index.jsp?page=itemDetail&iid=123206 '''Double Helix''', Really Good Music Publishing] * [https://www.firstcom.com/en-us/search?q=35703_1326&qtext=Twice%20is%20Nice&vtag=1&vwave=1&vdesc=1&ktype=1 '''Universal Publishing Production Music'''] * [https://www.firstcom.com/en-us/search?q=35703_1326&qtext=Twice%20is%20Nice&vtag=1&vwave=1&vdesc=1&ktype=1 '''FirstCom Production Music'''] {{portal bar|music|jazz}} {{Jack Cooper (musician)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Double Helix (music composition)}} [[Category:Television soundtracks]] [[Category:Jazz compositions]] [[Category:Television music]] [[Category:Swing music]] [[Category:Blues songs]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Use British English|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Friday Night Dinner | image = Friday night dinner.png | caption = | genre = [[Sitcom]]
[[Cringe comedy]] | creator = [[Robert Popper]] | writer = Robert Popper | director = [[Steve Bendelack]]
Martin Dennis | starring = [[Tamsin Greig]]
[[Paul Ritter (actor)|Paul Ritter]]
[[Simon Bird]]
[[Tom Rosenthal]]
[[Mark Heap]] | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_series = 5 | num_episodes = 31 | list_episodes = List of Friday Night Dinner episodes | executive_producer = [[Nira Park]]
Caroline Leddy
[[Kenton Allen]] | producer = Robert Popper | location = | runtime = 21-25 minutes | company = [[Robert Popper|Popper Pictures]]
[[Big Talk Productions]] | composer = "[[Meddle (song)|Meddle]]" by [[Little Boots]]
"Fot i hose" by [[Casiokids]]
"[[1901 (song)|1901]]" by [[Phoenix (band)|Phoenix]]
"Believe E.S.P." by Deerhoof
"Walk The Line" (Original Mix) by [[Dani Siciliano]] | opentheme = "[[Animal (Miike Snow song)|Animal]]" (Punks Jump Up Remix) by [[Miike Snow]] | distributor = [[BBC Studios]] | channel = [[Channel 4]] | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | audio_format = Stereo | first_aired = {{Start date|2011|2|25|df=y}} | last_aired = present }} '''''Friday Night Dinner''''' is a [[British television]] [[British sitcom|sitcom]] written by [[Robert Popper]] and starring [[Tamsin Greig]], [[Paul Ritter (actor)|Paul Ritter]], [[Simon Bird]], [[Tom Rosenthal]], and [[Mark Heap]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/feb/12/channel4-television|title=Tamsin Greig and Pulling's Paul Ritter to star in Channel 4 comedy|last=Plunkett|first=John|date=12 February 2010|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=13 February 2011}} The comedy is focused on the regular dinner experience of a [[British Jews|British Jewish]] Goodman family every Friday night. It began airing on 25 February 2011 on [[Channel 4]]. The fifth series concluded on 8 June 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/news/2739/friday_night_dinner_series_5/ |title=Friday Night Dinner Series 5 confirmed |publisher=British Comedy Guide |date=23 August 2017 |accessdate=23 August 2017}} ==Premise== ''Friday Night Dinner'' depicts [[Shabbat dinner]] in the middle-class [[Jewish secularism|secular Jewish]] Goodman family, reflecting writer and producer Robert Popper's own secular Jewish upbringing.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/mar/03/tamsin-greig-interview|title=Tamsin Greig: 'I always think I'll never work again'|first=Emine|last=Saner|work=The Guardian|date=4 March 2011}} It is set in suburban North London, and filmed there, in [[Mill Hill]].[http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/life/953236/friday-night-dinner-cast-simon-bird-tom-rosenthal-tamsin-greig Friday Night Dinner stars Simon Bird and Tom Rosenthal talk returning to the show] The family consists of father Martin ([[Paul Ritter (actor)|Paul Ritter]]), mother Jackie ([[Tamsin Greig]]), elder son and musician Adam ([[Simon Bird]]), and younger son and estate agent Jonny ([[Tom Rosenthal]]). The stories follow the family as they have their dinner, which is often interrupted by Adam and Jonny pranking each other and by their strange, lonely, friendless next-door neighbour Jim ([[Mark Heap]]), who is sexually attracted to Jackie and terrified of his own dog Wilson. Jackie's best friend, Val ([[Tracy-Ann Oberman]]), is also a frequent visitor, as well as Jackie's mother, Grandma Nelly ([[Frances Cuka]]). There are strong elements of farce throughout. ==Cast and characters== ===Main characters=== The following is a list of series regulars from ''Friday Night Dinner'', with actors credited in order that they were first credited in the series. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:73%;" |- ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:17%" | Character ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:14%" | Actor ! colspan="6" scope="col" style="width:42%" | Series |- ! scope="col" style="width:6%" | 1 ! scope="col" style="width:6%" | 2 ! scope="col" style="width:6%" | 3 ! scope="col" style="width:6%" | 4 ! scope="col" style="width:6%" | 5 |- | scope="row" | Adam Goodman | [[Simon Bird]] | colspan="5" {{yes2|'''Main'''}} |- | scope="row" | Jonathan "Jonny" Goodman | [[Tom Rosenthal]] | colspan="5" {{yes2|'''Main'''}} |- | scope="row" | Jackie Goodman | [[Tamsin Greig]] | colspan="5" {{yes2|'''Main'''}} |- | scope="row" | Martin Goodman | [[Paul Ritter (actor)|Paul Ritter]] | colspan="5" {{yes2|'''Main'''}} |- | scope="row" | Jim Bell | [[Mark Heap]] | colspan="5" {{yes2|'''Main'''}} |- | scope="row" | "Auntie" Val Lewis | [[Tracy-Ann Oberman]] | colspan = "5" {{no2|'''Recurring'''}} |- | scope="row" | Grandma Eleanor "Nelly" Buller | [[Frances Cuka]] | colspan = "5" {{no2|'''Recurring'''}} |} ==Episode lists== {{Main article|List of Friday Night Dinner date|df=yes|2011|4|8}} |- | scope="row" style="background: #A42B2B;"| | [[List of Friday Night Dinner episodes#Series 2 (2012)|2]] | style="padding: 0 8px;"| 6 | style="padding: 0 8px;"| {{Start Special (2012)|Special]] | style="padding: 0 8px;" colspan="2"| {{Start date|df=yes|2012|12|24}} |- | scope="row" style="background: #D7A037;"| | [[List of Friday Night Dinner episodes#Series 3 date|df=yes|2018|05|04}} | style="padding: 0 8px;"| {{End date|df=yes|2018|06|08}} |} ==American remake== In September 2011, ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' announced that [[Greg Daniels]], who had adapted ''[[The Office (UK TV series)|The Office]]'' for American television, would spearhead an American remake of the series for the broadcast network [[NBC]].{{cite web|last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/09/greg-daniels-to-adapt-british-comedy-friday-night-dinner-for-nbc/ |title=Greg Daniels To Adapt British Comedy 'Friday Night Dinner' For NBC |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=6 September 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2012}} The remake was picked up for a pilot, written by Daniels and directed by [[Ken Kwapis]]{{cite web|last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/02/ken-kwapis-set-to-direct-nbc-pilot-friday-night-dinner-reunites-with-greg-daniels/ |title=Ken Kwapis Set To Direct NBC Pilot 'Friday Night Dinner', Reunites With Greg Daniels |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=3 February 2012 |accessdate=4 February 2012}} and starring [[Allison Janney]] and [[Tony Shalhoub]] as the mother and father.{{cite web|last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/02/allison-janney-tony-shalhoub-to-star-in-greg-daniels-nbc-pilot-friday-night-dinner/ |title=Allison Janney & Tony Shalhoub To Star in Greg Daniels' NBC Pilot 'Friday Night Dinner' |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=7 February 2012 |accessdate=7 February 2012}} The pilot did not go to series. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links==
